I'm a rebel) The first person will then yell out "left," or "right," (depending on which side they chose) and then yell every number on that side. Hopefully the first person also finds his own on that side, which is bill number 1. If number 2 heard "2" yelled by the first person, they will go to the same side the first person went, (note that the first person also calls out which side they went, left or right) and go through all of those boxes until they find their own. If the second person does not hear "2" yelled by the first person, they will instead go the opposite direction. People 3-100 will do the same thing that person 2 did. Yes- I go into the room, and I open the box that has the same position as me. (So if I'm 7th, so I open the 7th box). Then I look at the bill inside. Whatever bill that is, I go to that place. (So if I see the bill inside is 8th, I go to the 8th box.) I either do this 50 times or until I find my bill. If I tell everyone to do this, it maximizes our chances of winning. I think this is because whatever loop I find myself in (I go to 7th, then it says go to the 8th, the 8th says go somewhere else...), I will always find myself in the loop that will eventually lead to my dollar, because of the place I started. The only problem is if my loop is longer than 50 boxes. But this is better odds than just looking randomly. This problem is called the 100 Prisoner's Problem if you want to look it up

So what I think:

Every person can look in 50/100 boxes. That gives each person a 1/2 chance of finding his bill.
Now if we have two people, there is only a 1/2^2=1/4 chance that both find their own bill. So there exists a 3/4 chance that there is at least one person who doesnt find the bill.
Continue this for all 100 people, gives a 1/2^100=0.0000000000000000000000000000008 chance of every person finding the bill.

So you shouldn't take the bet, since the payout of 1:101 is nothing compared to the miniscule chance of you winning the bet.

When the first person enters, unfortunately there's nothing he can do to overcome the 50/50. However, he can leave information behind. By agreeing to look at the first five rows of boxes, he can leave closed those with a value less than 50 and open the ones bigger than 50. The next person can do the same with the remaining 50 unchecked boxes, leaving everyone else with perfect information. Hence the probability of winning with this strategy is 1/4, giving an expected value of (1/4)(100)+(3/4)(-1) which is $24.25.

No, don't take the bet.  Each person has a 1/2 chance of finding their bill.  To find out the probability of two people finding their bills, you multiply (1/2)(1/2), which equals 1/4.  To add the probability of a third person finding their bill to those two, you multiply the result from the last equation by 1/2; (1/4)(1/2)=1/8.  That's the same as (1/2)^3.  From there, we can figure out that (1/2)^4=1/16, (1/2)^5=1/32, ect.  So the odds of everybody finding their bill is (1/2)^100, which is one in 7.89 times 10^-31.  So for every 7.89 times 10^31 times that you do this bet, the people hiding the bills will win.  Don't take it.

I suppose I had an idea around the same time as Hassan(this is a repost), with a similar logic(we both assume that those outside have a watch. Feedback?

 If no communication simply means no visual or audible interaction, and the next person is called immediately after the successful person leaves the room(big assumption), then there is an alternate solution, with a 50% chance of winning.
The 100 people line up to go into the room in order. The 1st person(call him “A”) goes in the room, and checks the bottom 50 boxes(the 1st half), in a snaking order(let’s assume the boxes are in a 10x10 grid). If he finds his bill(50% chance), then he leaves at an hour mark representing which box he found bill #1, and the minute mark where he found #2, if he found bill #2. Ex: Bill #1 found at the 14th box, and bill #2 found at the 45th box, so he leaves after 14 hours and 45 minutes. If bill #2 was not found, he leaves at 14 hours and 0 minutes. Note: I think he is able to check 50 boxes even after his own bill is found because in the video it said that he left the room when he “[showed him that he had succeeded]”.

Assuming that “A” found the bill, the 2nd person(call him “B”) has a 100% chance of finding bill #2.

 Case 1: Say “B” was called into the room at 14:45, then “B” would check all of the 1st half for where bill #3 was, and for continuity’s sake, leave at hour 45, and the minute marking where he found bill #3. If bill #3 was not found, then he would leave at 45:00.

Case 2: Say “B” was called into the room at 14:00, then “B” would check the 2nd half(top 50, starting from box #51) for where bill #2 was, and leave at the corresponding hour marker for that location(let’s say the 13th hour, as in the 13th box of the 2nd half), and the corresponding minute marker for where bill #3 was found. For example, if bill #3 was found at the 29th block, “B” would leave at 13:29 If bill #3 was not found, then “B” would leave at 13:00.

“C”, repeats the pattern, and so forth. After each turn, the people in line are basically building a coordinate system telling them which bills have been claimed (the boxes do not move). After 50 people have repeated these steps, people 51-100 can open the remaining 50 unknown boxes to find their own bill. 

Yes, you could claim that they couldn't accurately measure the time, but it’d be strange for 100 people not to have a watch/phone. Alternatively, we could switch hours to days and minutes to half hours, if that would make counting easier.

Yes, take the bet as there is a 0.3267 chance of winning.
Let's consider the following strategy. Label the people a1, ..., ak, ..., a100 and the boxes b1, ..., b100. For each person, he/she uses the following strategy: the person ak first opens bk. If the money in bk belongs the ak, then he/she is done. Otherwise, the money in bk belongs to some person aj, so ak then opens locker bj. This process is continued until either ak finds his/her money, or he/she has opened 50 boxes. Note that this process can always be continued. 
Next, note that the arrangement of the money corresponds to a permutation in [100]. Our strategy fails iff the permutation contains a cycle of size greater than 50. So it suffices to count the number of such permutations. 
Note that given 0<=r<=100, there are (n Choose r)(r-1)!(n-r)!=n!/r permutations of size r. So we have a total of sum n!/r, r goes from 51 to 100, permutations. 
Therefore the probability is sum 1/r, where r goes form 51 to 100. Using logarithmic approximation for the sum, we see that there is about ln(100/51) = 0.6733 chance of failing. So the chance of winning is about 0.3267.

EDIT: I think this strategy should be optimal. But I don't see a way of proving this. If anyone knows how to prove it, please let me know.

The first person should start with box 1, the second person on box 2, third on box 3, and so on.
Whatever bill they find in that box, should be the next box to go to, and they should keep doing this until they find their bill, or until they've hit their 50th box and failed.  Each person will find that they are in a chain, and their box will be the last one in that chain. If the chain size is more than 50, they will fail.

This is all down to the chains that are formed when the boxes are shuffled.  If a single chain exists containing more than 50 boxes, they will fail - and the odds of this happening is about 70%.

This works because people can go in in different orders (doesn't have to be 1,2,3...).

1) Everyone has a watch (or share a watch).
2) The first person goes in and flips open the first box. The person takes 10 minutes (so he/she has time to open 50 of the boxes) and adds the number on the bill (in seconds). For example, if the number in the first box is 30 then it becomes 10 minutes + 30 seconds. That is the time the person will spend in the room.
3) The person then flips open 49 more boxes to find his bill. If he/she doesn't, then it's game over. If the bill is found, then they win (if no one else screws up).
4) The person stays in the room for the amount of time in step 2 (10 min and 30 sec in the example).
5) The person with the number (30, derived from 10 min & 30 sec - 10 min) goes in the room and flips open the first box, takes out his bill, opens the second box and take the number on the bill and add, let's say 1 minute to it (they will have to agree on the time before the bet starts). The person then leaves after 1 minute + that number of seconds.
6) Repeat step 5 until all 100 people got their bill.

This only has a 50/50 chance of working, but they get 101 times the amount of money if they win, so on average they get 50.5 times of what they started with.

I say no. Without any strategy, and with truly randomized boxes and no post-peek communication, each player has 1/2 chance of finding their bill. There are 100 players, so the chances of EVERYONE finding their bill is 1/(2^100) = = = 7.88860905 x 10^-31. I would NOT take a bet whose chance of winning has 30 decimal 0's in front of it, even if I only lose a dollar.

Now, what if there's a strategy? What might that be? Well, the boxes are randomized, so we can have no prior knowledge about where each bill is. The room is completely reset after each player leaves, so no clues can be gleaned about any previous states. There's no communication between players after the initial strategy conception, so there's no way to learn about any other players' information.

I can't see any possible strategy given those restrictions--each time a player enters the room, it's effectively a completely random choice of 50 boxes, no matter what algorithm you choose when picking.

If everyone guesses at random with no strategy there is a (1/2)^100 or 7.1X10^-31 chance of getting it right. Obviously this includes situations where no one guesses in a particular box and there is no chance of everyone getting the right answer. With a little planning this could be avoided. For example, the first 50 people can guess in the first 50 boxes and the last 50 people can guess in the last 50 boxes. To find the probability now we can divide the number of ways the boxes can be organized with the first 50 bills in the first 50 boxes divided by the total number of ways the boxes can be organized or 50!50!/100! which equals 9.9X10^-30. Over ten times more likely, yet still immensely improbable. Maybe there is a better strategy that can be implemented but that is the best I can come up with.

Because everyone is putting down the correct answer of 7.8886^-31, let me explain. Each person gets the same chance at getting their number (50% or .5 for calculation purposes) and there are 100 people going through the 50:50 gamble. To understand why the expression .5^100 or 7.8886^-31 is right let's look at it for 3 people. If person 1 has a 50% chance and person 2 has a 50% chance then the chance that they both get it right is the product of their individual probabilities or 25%. then add person 3 with another 50% chance and multiply those together (.25 x .5 = .125) and you get 12.5%. With only 2 extra people your chance of winning has gone from 1/2 to 1/8. Now just repeat that 100 times instead of three and someone just made $100 (the administrator of the game)

Divide the 100 boxes into set 1, and set 2. Person 1 enters the room and searches set 1. He has a 50% chance of finding his bill. He also searches for the person 2's bill. He then somehow communicates to rest that he either did, or did not find the next persons bill. (The best way of doing so would be by the amount of time you stay in the room.) If person 1 did find it, then person 2 also searches set 1 and looks for person 3's bill. If person 1 did not, then person 2 knows they will find their bill in set 2. The system repeats and everyone except person 1 is guaranteed to find their bill. Total chance is 50%.

Its simple...
Person X opens box X, looks inside if box X has bill Y , he goes to box Y next and so on for 50 attempts. The probability that he won't find bill X with this process in 50 attempts  is equal to the probability that all 50 of these numbers are not in the box marked corresponding to them and that's incredibly low.

There is a way to do it and have a decent chance of winning, but it's hard to explain why it works. The strategy is this : 
Player number "n" (number of his bill) goes into the room and looks into the n'th box. He/she will find a bill there, bill number x, he then goes to box number x and so on...
Given the finite number of boxes, this process will eventually loop to bill number "n". If this loop is reached before 50 boxes are open, the player will find his/her bill. 
The advantage here is that the success of all the participants depends solely on the inexistence of a loop that's greater than 50 in the set of boxes. The odds that all loops are smaller than 50 is about 1/3, given the huge outcome, it's totally worth playing.

I don't know a good strategy, but here's what we do know:
- There are bad strategies, if everyone opens the same 50 boxes, half is not going to find its bill, so you automatically lose. There are a lot of permutations where some boxes go unopened, those are all definitely losing strategies.
- Our chance of winning only has to be 1% or more for this to be profitable
- It's probably easier to first imagine this problem with something like 4 people and 4 boxes, it's the same problem but simpler.
- If you try it with 2 people and 2 boxes, and you don't play a definite losing strategy, your chances are always 50%, just pick the box the other doesn't. But that's too simple and doesn't really get us anywhere.
- We probably want to set it up in such a way that we either all lose or we all win, depending on the position of the boxes. Because if our losses are distributed, we never get all the bills and never win.

SIMPLE
 no rules say you have to take all your attempts the first time you enter the room, no one said you can't go back into the room multiple times as long as you have attempts left, AND no one said you can't continue to make attempts even after you've found your bill... you're just not allowed to communicate with each other. before starting, have the 100 people divide up into 25 groups of 4, so persons 1,2,3 and 4 are in group 1. persons 5,6,7,and 8 are in group 2. people go into to the rooms 1 at a time and make one attempt. so all 100 people make the 1st attempt, then all 100 people make their 2nd attempt.

Now each group also divides up the boxes they'll check in their attempts, so in group 1 person #1 will check boxes 1,5,9,etc. and person #2 will check boxes 2,6,10,etc. When a person finds a bill that belongs to anyone in the group, including their own, they skip their next attempt. so without communicating anything to the other people in their group they all can deduce that the bill in that box belongs to one of them. 

By attempt 25 everyone should know that one of the 4 boxes (which caused a partner to skip their turn) contains their bill.
By attempt 29 everyone should find their bill. 

you could have everyone increase their group size up to  ( i think) 7-8 and they could find their bill by attempt 21-22.

With a 50% chance of win, they should take the bet. The winning strategy depends on the following assumptions:

1. They can stay in the room for any duration of time, i.e., a person can stay longer even after he finds his bill.
2. After a person leaves, the other person enters the room soon (within a minute or so).
3. Everyone has some kind of watch with themselves to keep track of time.

Here is the strategy.

1. They choose the order by which they enter the room like 1, 2, 3, and so on.
2. First person enters the room and peeks in the first 50 boxes.
3. With 50% chance he will find his bill.
4. He also checks if he finds the 2nd person's bill.
5. If he finds 2nd bill he will leave early (say, within 5 minutes of entering the room), otherwise he will stay longer.
6. By counting the duration 1st person stays in the room, 2nd person knows if his bill is in the first 50 boxes or the second boxes. He peeks those 50 boxes and finds his bill.
7. Second person also checks if he sees 3rd person's bill and based on it he knows if 3rd bill is in the first 50 boxes or in the last 50 boxes.
8. Similar to 1st person, 2nd person leaves early if 3rd person's bill is in the first 50 boxes otherwise stay longer.
9. Continuing this approach, all 100 people know in which 50 boxes their bill are. So, apart from the first person, they all find their bill. Only point of failure is the first person, who have chance of success of 50%.

Number the boxes 1-100 in order, so that each box corresponds to a bill.

This deal is literally unwinnable. The way you find average payout is to add value*probability for each outcome. In this case that is 101*(.5^100)+ 1*(1(.5^100)) which equals -1. That means that the payout has an average of -1. The only way that is possible is if no one ever won and 101 dollars was never given out, which would be
101*0 + -1*(1) = -1. You literally have a 0 percent chance of winning, hence the title.

I have not take statistics yet, but I think the trick is that everyone has to find their bill. Although for each individual, the chances of finding their bill is 50%, the chances of everyone all 100 participant finding their bill is incredibly small. Look at these numbers...

The first person enters the room, there is a 1/2 chance of finding the bill. After the second person enters, the chance is halved to 1/4, which is the likelihood both participants have found their bill. By the third person, the chance is 1/8, By the fourth person, the chance of everyone finding their bill is 1/16, and so on.

The formula seems to be participants' likelihood of them finding their bill, to the power of the number of participants. Say P is participants, then the formula mathematically represented (1/(2P))^2. After the 100th person, the chances of everyone finding the bill and winning the bet is only 1 out of 26765060022282299401496703205376!!!!!

That is roughly only a 7.8 times 10^-29% chance of winning, yes, a 0.000000000000000000000000000078% chance!﻿

Yes.
Each person chooses the number that they are (person #4 chooses box #4).  If there are not successful (box #4 had #23's dollar) you then look in box #23.  Repeat.
This problem boils down to how long linked-lists or loops would form randomly in a set of 100.  If a loop is "closed" at distance less than 50 you will succeed -- somewhere in the chain it points back to box #4 -- and that's your dollar!  It can't be in any other loop/chain in the set of 100.
Some intuition and quick calculations put this at about 70% that the chains would be less than 50.

(1) Earthling #1 goes into the room and opens half of the boxes. 
(2) If she dosn't find his bill : Game over. If not, continue
(3) Before leaving, she memorizes (or writes down) the content of all 50 open boxes.
(4) She leaves the room and travels back in time, to the time before she entered the room.
(5) She tells the other guys via telepathy or cellphone what's in the 50 boxes he opened. (Note that due to the time travel trick, this happens before she enters the room, so it's allowed.)
(6) Earthling #2 enters the room. 
(7a) If she knows from #1 where his bill was, she opens this box, plus 49 of the 50 boxes #1 didn't open.
(7b) If she doesn't know, she opens the 50 boxes #1 didn't open.
(8) In both cases she finds her bill and knows the content of all boxes. (In case 7a she knows what's in 99 boxes and can conclude what's in the last one).
(9) She leaves the room, travels back in time and tells the others via telepathy or phone where which bill is.
(10) Now everybody knows what's in all the boxes, so the rest is trivial.
